p.seg: The royal axe is by no means an instrument for one generation:
Its abundant virtue is elevated and imposing.
Concerning the Way has altogether four things to investigate:
the first is heaven,
the second is earth,
the third is man,
the fourth is fate.
Among men there are five five types of people to flock to you:
the first type are those a hundred times better than oneself,
the second are those ten times better than oneself,
the third are equal to oneself,
the fourth are domestic employees,
and the fifth are slaves.
What is called Heaven,
are the principles and the real essence of things.
What is called Earth,
is what is constantly there and will not move away.
What is called the human,
is the hatred of death and delight in life.
What is called fate,
is never other than what depends on the ruler. [XENOPHANES ADUMBRATED]
As for the lord,
keeps order in the realm of the spirits;
the realm of the spirits
has man as its basis; [XENOPHANES!!!!!]
Man
is based on the worthies and sages as their basis;
The worthies and sages
are based on selection from a wide spectrum;
selection from a broad spectrum
is based on the five types of people who flock to you.
Thus, if facing north (like a minister), you serve your subordinates,
then those who have a hundred times your calibre will flock to you.
If to begin with you hasten along but afterwards you slacken off
if you first ask advice but then fall silent
then those who have ten times your calibre will flock to you.
If when others scuffle along you yourself also scuffle along
then those equal to yourself will flock to you.
If you stoop over your table or lean on your cane,
and give orders by pointing and signaling,
then "servants" will arrive.
If you keep sighing with delight and shout with pain
then "slaves" will arrive.
Thus, the true emperor dwells with teachers
a typical king dwells with friends;
a ruler doomed to ruin dwells with his slaves.
Hence, who has power over a myriad men,
we call "talented";
over a thousand men,
"valiant",
over a hundred men,
"splendid."
What has power over tones
is what we call sounds：
I have never heard of a tone sent out
and the echo surpassing the sound of it.
The noble have knowledge;
the rich property;
the poor their bodies.
When token and tally don't match,
affairs, when undertaken, don't succeed.
Without death, no life;
without cutting, no success.
Reward by calculating achievements,
pronounce by weighing power。
If the kingly blade lies herein,
who would be able to cause confusion?

div.head: 2 著希第二 Shedding light on expectations

p.seg: Hence, those who put their hopes on his person,
never go against his feelings;
those who their hopes on others
never abuse their guests.
Wildness in manners shares the patterns of beasts;
brutality of language shares the expressions with barbarians.
A true gentleman,
may be easily treated on friendly terms, but cannot easily be made familiar;
he may fear misfortune, but cannot easily be made to back off;
he may be fond of profit, but does not do anything wrong;
he may move timely, but doesn't start anything inappropriately.
Only when one's body may find ease with someone, but one does not dare to dwell there,
ceremony has come about;
only when one's heart may desire something, but one does not dare to rely on it ,
appropriateness has come about.
Appropriateness is being orderly through the discipline of desires;
ceremony is discriminating by returning to one's feelings.
It is therefore that the gentleman does not act out anything directly from his feelings.
But the one who brings disorder in the world,
takes mediocre knowledge as a great idea,
central defile as the way,
and profit-seeking as his authentic feelings.
If one does not share his dislikes, one is not able to be on friendly terms with him;
if one does share his dislikes, there is still mutual dislike.
When advisers pronounce on what is good, he considers it fraud;
when they expound on what is right, he considers it bragging;
when they equanimously and directly report to him, he still doesn't trust them.
It is therefore that the person of worth in a disorderly age,
cutting off relations, has no position from where to communicate;
differing in kind, has no means to report,
How bitter
that a person of worth hides in a disorderly age!
If on top there is a negligent lord,
below there are no straight statements.
If the lord has an arrogant attitude,
the people have many taboos.
Hence, men go against their genuine abilities,
officials hide their real feelings：
while in their hearts they may be dissatisfied, they do not dare not to praise him;
while in service they may not approve of him, they do not dare not to work hard;
even if in their policies they do not agree, they do not dare not to follow him.
It is therefore that, when observing a person of worth in a disorderly age,
one should be careful not to take this as his definite feelings.

div.head: 3 夜行第三 Procedure by night

p.seg: They all have their tests,
something that makes them as they are.
But, behind, we don't see its back,
in front, we don't see its head.
Achieving success and following up tasks,
nobody knows its qualities.
Pictures are not able to potray it,
words not able to mention it.
Forced to give it an explanation, I say：
Vast! vague!
Yet within is an image
Vague! vast!
Yet within is something.
Dark! mysterious!
Yet within is a quintessence.
Taking reliability to the utmost and scrutinizing the authentic,
he returns to the featureless.
Where even ghosts are not able to see,
he is able to work for others.
Hence, the sage values procedure by night.
